bioghist.p: Ernst Schäfer (1910-1992) was a famous German hunter and zoologist in the 1930s, specializing in ornithology. He is most famous for his three expeditions to Tibet in 1931, 1934-1935, and 1938-1939, the first two led by the Academy's Brooke Dolan II, and the third led by himself under the patronage of Himmler's Ahnenerbe organization. Schäfer wrote several books, including Berge, Buddhas und Bären (Mountains, Buddhas and Bears), and helped produce the film Geheimnis Tibet (Secret Tibet).

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers related to Schäfer's participation in the Academy's expeditions in the 1930s to Tibet. Materials include correspondence between Robert M. Peck and Schäfer, in German with English translations by Mary Dolack. Peck was seeking information about the Dolan expeditions for the Academy's 175 anniversary exhibits. The collection also includes excerpts of writings by Schäfer about the Dolan expedition, translated into English by Mary Dolack, and photocopies of pictures taken by Schäfer during the expedition. Other documents in the collection are several letters regarding Schäfer/Dolan materials in the holdings of the Library of Congress and one about the provenance of the adult giant pandas in the Academy's collection.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

relatedmaterial.p: Related material may be found in the following collections: Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia: Brooke Dolan papers (collection 64) and Robert Peck papers.
